newsitem.title: JAPAN: NTT seeks patents for electronic money.
newsitem.headline: NTT seeks patents for electronic money.

text.p: Domestic telecommunications giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (NTT) has applied for patents in Japan for its electronic money system, NTT officials told a news conference on Wednesday.

The system, an improved experimental version of one unveiled by NTT last December, would store electronic cash on an IC (integrated circuit) card and allow transfer at shops or over a network like the Internet, the officials said.
The NTT system, refined with the aid of a Bank of Japan think-tank, calls for a separate institution to issue the electronic money and another body to register users.

Hiroshi Yasuda, director of NTT Information and Communications Systems Laboratories, said it was not clear who would set up the issuing and user registration bodies, nor was there a set schedule for pilot tests of the system, although most technological barriers had been cleared.
He also said it was difficult to predict how long it would be before electronic money would be in widespread use, although perhaps that might happen by the year 2010.
"It depends on how acceptable it is to users," Yasuda said.
Other experimental electronic cash systems include Mondex, the brainchild of Britain's National Westminster Bank Plc and Amsterdam-based DigiCash Inc's E-Cash.
